title: How to Create a Garden of Fragrant Australian Plants

steps.headline: Choose boronia.
steps.description: Without a doubt, this is one of the best known Australian fragrant plants. The best choice with the strongest fragrance is the brown variety. The pink variety (Boronia floribunda) has a slight fragrance that is hard to detect. The Sydney native rose (Boronia serrulata) is another choice but also of faint fragrance.

steps.headline: Grow the native frangipani (hymenosporum flavum).
steps.description: It grows into a tree with very fragrant flowers.

steps.headline: Grow the mint bush.
steps.description: It has a mint-like fragrance coming from the foliage. It has lovely flowers (blue or white).

steps.headline: Choose other fragrant plants.
steps.description: Visit the local nursery to ask for their advice about other fragrant natives suitable for your region. Some additional ideas include: P. ovalifolia; P. rotundifolia; P. incisa; and P. teretifolia. These plants all have varying shades of pink, purple and mauve and like to grow in a sunny or slightly-shaded position.

text: Choose boronia. Without a doubt, this is one of the best known Australian fragrant plants. The best choice with the strongest fragrance is the brown variety. The pink variety (Boronia floribunda) has a slight fragrance that is hard to detect. The Sydney native rose (Boronia serrulata) is another choice but also of faint fragrance. Grow the native frangipani (hymenosporum flavum). It grows into a tree with very fragrant flowers. Grow the mint bush. It has a mint-like fragrance coming from the foliage. It has lovely flowers (blue or white). Choose other fragrant plants. Visit the local nursery to ask for their advice about other fragrant natives suitable for your region. Some additional ideas include: P. ovalifolia; P. rotundifolia; P. incisa; and P. teretifolia. These plants all have varying shades of pink, purple and mauve and like to grow in a sunny or slightly-shaded position.
